taxonAuthor: Maneveldt, Hughey, P.W. Gabrielson & S.Y. Jeong, 2024

texts.shortText:
These two forms cannot be differentiated in the field but have been shown to be genetically distinct species, so are treated together here.

They form thin, pale, rosy-pink sheets that encrust bedrock and especially loose pebbles and boulders. They can have a matt to glossy appearance and although flat and fairly featureless, often have a pitted surface due to sunken conceptacles. Individuals remain distinguishable, but are confluent and can coalesce to cover large areas.
Typically only about 1 mm thick, but can be 100 mm or more across.

Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional:  C acervata False Bay to Kwazulu-Natal; C. roseola Cape Peninsula to East London.

Both species common on both bedrock and especially on loose boulders and pebbles, which is an unusual habitat and indicated these are pioneer species able to survive frequent disturbance when these loose stones are rolled during storms. Found from the mid- to low intertidal to a depth of about 14 m.
Reproductive conceptacles occur in pits on the thallus surface.

These species can be distinguished from most other coralline algae due to their ability to live on small, loose pebbles and stones that are often tumbled by the waves. Also by the smooth surface marked by regulalry spaces pits when reproductive conceptacles are present.

Jeong, SY, Diaz‐Pulido, G, Maneveldt, GW, Gabrielson, PW, Nelson, WA, Won, BY & Cho, TO (2022). Phymatolithopsis gen. nov. (Hapalidiales, Corallinophycidae, Rhodophyta) based on molecular and morpho‐anatomical evidence. Journal of Phycology, 58(1), 161-178.

Maneveldt, GW, Jeong, SY, Hughey, JR & Gabrielson, PW (2024). Phymatolithopsis acervata comb. nov., and P. roseola sp. nov.(Hapalidiales, Rhodophyta) from South Africa with a comment on infraordinal classification. Botanica Marina, 67(3), 249-275.
